statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Fordham 45, Richmond 37
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- Bryant Dunston and Jermaine Anderson made just enough baskets Wednesday night to help Fordham beat Richmond 45-37 in the lowest-scoring game in Atlantic 10 tournament history. The 82 combined points were the fewest in tournament history, eclipsing West Virginia's 44-41 victory over Temple in a 1992 semifinal. Only about 200 fans stuck around for the second half, when the teams went 6½ minutes without a field goal. Dunston had 14 points and Anderson added 13, sending Fordham (15-15) into a second-round matchup against La Salle, the tournament's No. 3 seed. Jermaine Bucknor, Richmond's leading scorer, had 12 points on 5-of-19 shooting. Richmond shot 26.8 percent from the field overall. Richmond finished last in the league in scoring, averaging only 54.4 points per game. The Spiders were held under 40 points for the fourth time this season. Their problems came into focus right away Wednesday, when they set an A10 tournament record by scoring only 16 points in the first half -- the fewest in any half of a first-round game. The previous record was 20 by Duquesne against Temple in 1997. The 16 points were a tournament record, but not a season low for the Spiders. Twice during the season, they were held to 14 points in the first half. The last time was during a 69-30 loss to Temple, the low point of their 0-9 February. Richmond went 1-for-9 from the field in the opening nine minutes, setting the tone. In one telling moment, 6-foot-11 center Drew Crank went up for a two-hand dunk, but 6-foot-7 forward Michael Binns outjumped him and knocked the ball out of his hands. Fordham couldn't exploit Richmond's latest offensive breakdown because the Rams weren't a whole lot better, opening the game in a 4-for-13 shooting funk. Jermaine Anderson's three 3-pointers helped Fordham pull ahead 23-16 at halftime. Center Kevin Steenberge opened the second half with a fadeaway jumper and a 3-pointer -- the Spiders' first back-to-back baskets of the game -- that cut it to 23-21. Fordham, which averages 69 points per game, never got into a flow against the Spiders' zone defense, making only one field goal in the first nine minutes of the second half. Neither team managed a basket during a 6½-minute span. With 10 minutes to go, Fordham was shooting 28 percent from the field, Richmond 26 percent. Dunston's three-point play and Anderson's 3-pointer gave Fordham its first double-digit lead, 38-26, with 5:26 to play. At that point, desperation set in on the Spiders. Bucknor took a shot from behind the NBA arc on the floor and missed everything. Fordham finally broke the 40-point mark when Michael Binns made two free throws with 1:46 to go. Richmond repeatedly fouled down the stretch, and the Rams went 15-of-25 overall from the line.
